Forza Horizon 5 hit me way harder than I expected. The whole vibe is just electric - Mexico feels like one massive sun-soaked festival where somethingâ€™s popping off every 100 meters. Events, races, wheelspins, new cars, seasonal stuffâ€¦ the game floods you with content to the point where 100 hours barely scratch the surface. And yeah, Iâ€™m already 80+ hours in, still glued to it like itâ€™s day one.

Gameplay? Super fun. The handling felt a bit sticky at first, especially on a controller, but that actually made it more addictive. Those cursed corners made me want to bump the difficulty, retry events, and actually learn how to take turns on a high-end car like a human being. The soundtrack slaps too - different stations, different moods, never gets dull.

Iâ€™m not a racing game person at all, I just love cars so the physics threw me off at first. But as soon as I got used to it, it turned into a whole advantage. Especially once you dive into the tuning and customization. Itâ€™s ridiculous how deep it goes. You can tweak weight, build parameters, tire pressure, engine setups - it all genuinely changes how each car feels.

The game both looks and sounds insane. Wet roads at night? Peak visuals. Absolute perfection. The sound design/engines/weather, everything just elevates it even more.

Favorite activities? Iâ€™m basic in the best way. Give me road races, closed-circuit races, anything on asphalt. Off-road? Miss me with that. But jumping into a new car and discovering how it behaves is pure dopamine. The more I unlock, the more I want to play - itâ€™s that kind of loop.

Now, the one thing that actually tilts me sometimes is the Drivatars. These bots straight up break the laws of physics, break my confidence and sometimes break my will to live. They get traction in places where your car just slides into the shadow realm. The fix? Either race real people online or mentally tune out the bots entirely and focus on your own run. If you stare at their behavior too long, it gets frustrating fast on high difficulty levels.

For [b] casual [/b] players, the map is always beautiful and very spacious - each time you drive, even often on the same roads, but at variable scenery (whether it's at the beach, atop of mountains, through the rainforest, or simply over the stretching desert roads) - these driving experiences will never ever feel the same each time, it's always different. 

Relaxed, cruising at controlled, enjoyable speeds, and simply appreciating the splendid views - that's the perfect recipe for a nice, 'spirited driving' experience.


From a [b] competitive [/b] standpoint, it's very easy, even for beginners, to obtain top tier cars and as well to apply free, community-made tunes shared by other players - to build a whole, challenge-worthy but widely varied garage, for relatively non-expensive in-game currencies, also easy to earn and not so timely.

Sometimes however, a few online race tracks might feel 'unforgiving', or the race itself might feel 'unfair' - mainly because of the tricky nature of challenging routes (no room for error or 'skill issues'), and/or also due to other players as well (too good/bad or 'lucky').

Regardless, as in other games, trying to complete the race is always a must for learning, and so is having good sportsmanship, as I very often noticed, is also present in this game (for instance, racers often using 'Link' (in-game, quick chat feature), to simply say 'sorry' when they make mistakes affecting/impacting other racers).


The game never lacks [b] content [/b], as quite regularly, new challenges/events are added to unlock exclusive and amazing cars (voted by players - very cool), which all players can then get for free (for points earned), and players can even claim any previous ones which they missed (requires a 'backstage pass' which costs higher points, but still free to unlock one previously missed, exclusive car per 'season' - from any earlier season - also very cool). This is yet another reason why many players, including myself often come back to the game.


I'd say that the [b] price [/b] is also very fair and reasonable - for the amount of content and gameplay, so it's very much worth its value, and even more so - at the 50% off discounted price, especially during certain Steam sales events.

I'd recommend playing this game using a controller, and of course, on a decent, average gaming rig (this game is also already optimized for your device after each update - very convenient)


[b] Overall [/b], I'd highly recommend this game, especially if you are fond of driving, racing or such simulation games. Even I still find it to be the most visually immersive driving game - with good, engaging and some random gameplay as well. Online competition and completing challenges are quite fun sometimes, but, I think it's much better to appreciate the drive along the relaxing views, one place at a time, y'know, and I'd suggest giving this a try too, from time to time.

At this point of time, if you are considering getting the game, it'd be much more worthwhile if you'd continue playing - because 150 GB is quite demanding. Another way is you could also use the Steam storage management feature (in settings) to transfer the game to another storage drive and play again later.


Forza Horizon 6 is also right around the corner (next year), so you could also consider skipping straight to that, however, expect full price for quite some while after release, before eventually the getting lower prices from much later sales events.

However, as seen from several recent games, the graphical recreation and maps of Japan have already been really impressive, and now it's only imaginable what FH6 is going to be like. Only time will tell, but it probably won't disappoint, that's for sure.

So, if you don't have FH5 already, I'd still recommend getting it as of right now, and I don't think that it would not be worth it. But again, certain things considered, it's always your choice.


Well, that's a pretty long review... I guess I might as well become a game critic now :3 
Nah but anyways, thanks for reading, I hope that in some way, you have gotten something out of this :>
I wish you a very happy gaming holiday!
